items.title: Government Begins to Reopen After Longest-Ever Shutdown: Trump Live Updates
Record US Shutdown Ends as Trump Signs Spending Bill
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump signed legislation to end the longest government shutdown in US history, marking the official conclusion to a 43-day impasse that halted food aid to millions of households, canceled thousands of flights and forced federal workers to go unpaid for more than a month. Trump's…
items.content: President Donald Trump signed legislation to end the longest government shutdown in US history, marking the official conclusion to a 43-day impasse that halted food aid to millions of households, canceled thousands of flights and forced federal workers to go unpaid for more than a month. items.title: Delta CEO reacts to end of government shutdown as travel chaos begins to soothe
items.standfirst: Delta CEO Ed Bastian joined "CBS Mornings" following the end of the longest U.S. government shutdown. The 43-day impasse impacted millions of Americans and thousands of scheduled flights. CBS News' Tom Hanson reports.
items.content: Delta CEO Ed Bastian joined "CBS Mornings" following the end of the longest U.S. government shutdown. The 43-day impasse impacted millions of Americans and thousands of scheduled flights. CBS News' Tom Hanson reports.

items.title: What’s the Biggest Risk to Stocks After the Government Shutdown?
Donald Trump signs funding bill, ending record 43-day government shutdown
items.standfirst: The US government isset taking its first tentative steps towards re-opening on Thursday after President Donald Trump signed a bill to end the longest federal shutdown in US history. The Republican-led House of Representatives voted on Wednesday, largely along party lines, to approve a Senate-passed package that will reopen federal departments and agencies, as many Democrats fume over what they see as a capitulation by party leaders. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Washington, Fraser Jackson.
items.content: The US government isset taking its first tentative steps towards re-opening on Thursday after President Donald Trump signed a bill to end the longest federal shutdown in US history. The Republican-led House of Representatives voted on Wednesday, largely along party lines, to approve a Senate-passed package that will reopen federal departments and agencies, as many Democrats fume over what they see as a capitulation by party leaders. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Washington, Fraser Jackson.

items.title: Delta CEO says air travel "should return to normal" by weekend after shutdown ends
items.standfirst: Delta CEO Ed Bastian told "CBS Mornings" he believes air travel "should return to normal" by this weekend after the government shutdown ended Wednesday night. He added that he has no concerns about upcoming Thanksgiving travel.
items.content: Delta CEO Ed Bastian told "CBS Mornings" he believes air travel "should return to normal" by this weekend after the government shutdown ended Wednesday night. He added that he has no concerns about upcoming Thanksgiving travel.

items.title: The government shutdown is over, but not everything is back to normal
items.standfirst: President Trump signed a bill reopening the government Wednesday night, but it will take more than a day for some things to return to business as usual. We're tracking those here.
items.content: President Trump signed a bill reopening the government Wednesday night, but it will take more than a day for some things to return to business as usual. We're tracking those here.(Image credit: Eric Lee)

items.title: Trump signs funding bill into law, ending longest government shutdown in U.S. history
items.standfirst: The longest government shutdown in U.S. history ended Wednesday after President Trump signed the funding bill into law. The House narrowly passed the funding package with six Democrats joining Republicans. Nikole Killion reports.
items.content: The longest government shutdown in U.S. history ended Wednesday after President Trump signed the funding bill into law. The House narrowly passed the funding package with six Democrats joining Republicans. Nikole Killion reports.

items.standfirst: Starbucks Workers United is calling the strike the "red cup rebellion," since it coincides with the coffee chain's annual Red Cup Day promotion.
items.content: Starbucks Workers United is calling the strike the "red cup rebellion," since it coincides with the coffee chain's annual Red Cup Day promotion.

items.title: ‘Whatever it takes’: Starbucks workers launch US strike and call for boycott
items.standfirst: Unfair labor practice strike on ‘red cup day’ in over 40 cities comes amid stagnant negotiations with coffee chainMore than a thousand Starbucks workers have commenced a strike in more than 40 cities across the US on Thursday amid stagnant negotiations with the world’s largest coffee chain over a first union contract.On the company’s annual “red cup day”, hailing the start of the lucrative holiday season, Starbucks Workers United is launching an unfair labor practice (ULP) strike, with rallies planned in locations including New York City; Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; Chicago, Illinois; Columbus, Ohio; and Anaheim, California. Continue reading...
items.content: Unfair labor practice strike on ‘red cup day’ in over 40 cities comes amid stagnant negotiations with coffee chainMore than a thousand Starbucks workers have commenced a strike in more than 40 cities across the US on Thursday amid stagnant negotiations with the world’s largest coffee chain over a first union contract.On the company’s annual “red cup day”, hailing the start of the lucrative holiday season, Starbucks Workers United is launching an unfair labor practice (ULP) strike, with rallies planned in locations including New York City; Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; Chicago, Illinois; Columbus, Ohio; and Anaheim, California. items.title: Pennsylvania senator John Fetterman sustains injury to face from fall outside his home
items.standfirst: Senator released humorous health update after he was released from hospital, suggesting he was doing wellUS politics live – latest updatesPennsylvania senator John Fetterman was hospitalized on Thursday after a heart condition flare-up caused him to fall on his face outside his home.According to a statement from his press secretary, the Democrat was taken to a Pittsburgh hospital following the early-morning slip, and doctors determined he had experienced ventricular fibrillation that left him feeling light-headed before he fell and sustained minor facial injuries. Continue reading...
items.content: Senator released humorous health update after he was released from hospital, suggesting he was doing wellUS politics live – latest updatesPennsylvania senator John Fetterman was hospitalized on Thursday after a heart condition flare-up caused him to fall on his face outside his home.According to a statement from his press secretary, the Democrat was taken to a Pittsburgh hospital following the early-morning slip, and doctors determined he had experienced ventricular fibrillation that left him feeling light-headed before he fell and sustained minor facial injuries. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Paris Remembers: 2015 terror attacks commemoration ceremony opens with music
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘The pain remains’: France remembers victims of 2015 Paris attacks

items.title: Paris Remembers: 2015 terror attacks commemoration ceremony opens with music
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. A year on, a commemoration ceremony took place to pay homage to the victims, with music and dance performances.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. A year on, a commemoration ceremony took place to pay homage to the victims, with music and dance performances.

items.title: Survivors of 2015 Paris terror attacks perform "You will never walk alone"
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. Ten years on, a choir made up of survivors and relatives of people who died performed "You will never walk alone" at a commemoration ceremony.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. Ten years on, a choir made up of survivors and relatives of people who died performed "You will never walk alone" at a commemoration ceremony.

items.title: 'Whoever attacks Paris attacks all of humanity': Ten years on, France commemorates terror attacks
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris killed 132 people, including two survivors who later died by suicide, and wounded at least 350. Many families now measure time as “before” and “after.” Ten years on, the mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo, gave a speech at the ceremony commemorating the victims of the attack.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris killed 132 people, including two survivors who later died by suicide, and wounded at least 350. Many families now measure time as “before” and “after.” Ten years on, the mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo, gave a speech at the ceremony commemorating the victims of the attack.

items.title: ‘The pain remains’: France remembers victims of 2015 Paris attacks
items.standfirst: Bells ring out across French capital marking 10th anniversary of country’s deadliest peacetime attackParis attacks anniversary – in picturesFrance has paid tribute to the 130 people killed 10 years ago by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers who targeted a stadium, bars, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall in the country’s deadliest peacetime attack.“The pain remains,” Emmanuel Macron wrote on social media on Thursday as he visited each of the sites that were attacked. Bells rang out across the city as a remembrance ceremony began at a memorial garden in central Paris attended by relatives and survivors. Continue reading...
items.content: Bells ring out across French capital marking 10th anniversary of country’s deadliest peacetime attackParis attacks anniversary – in picturesFrance has paid tribute to the 130 people killed 10 years ago by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers who targeted a stadium, bars, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall in the country’s deadliest peacetime attack.“The pain remains,” Emmanuel Macron wrote on social media on Thursday as he visited each of the sites that were attacked. Bells rang out across the city as a remembrance ceremony began at a memorial garden in central Paris attended by relatives and survivors. Continue reading...

items.title: Ten years after the Paris 2015 terror attacks, heroes read out the names of victims
items.standfirst: Ten years ago, 132 people were killed by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers in the deadliest attack in France's modern history. Ten years later to the day, heroes read out the names of the 132 victims who died that horrific evening, during a commemoration ceremony.
items.content: Ten years ago, 132 people were killed by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers in the deadliest attack in France's modern history. Ten years later to the day, heroes read out the names of the 132 victims who died that horrific evening, during a commemoration ceremony.

items.title: Dancers perform emotional choreography at 2015 Paris terror attack commemoration
items.standfirst: France marks a decade since suffering its deadliest terrorist attack in modern history. Ten years on, a commemoration ceremony took place in Paris to pay tribute the victims, which included dancers perfoming an emotional choreography.
items.content: France marks a decade since suffering its deadliest terrorist attack in modern history. Ten years on, a commemoration ceremony took place in Paris to pay tribute the victims, which included dancers perfoming an emotional choreography.

items.title: 'Life is stronger than death': France remembers its victims, ten years after the 2015 terror attacks
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, France experienced its deadliest attacks on French soil since World War Two, scarring the national psyche and prompting emergency security measures, many of which are now embedded in law. Ten years on, Philippe Duperron, president of the Victims association "13onze15" gave an opening speech at the ceremony commemorating the attacks.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, France experienced its deadliest attacks on French soil since World War Two, scarring the national psyche and prompting emergency security measures, many of which are now embedded in law. Ten years on, Philippe Duperron, president of the Victims association "13onze15" gave an opening speech at the ceremony commemorating the attacks.

items.title: Choir and orchestra perform 'Requiem of Light' at 2015 terror attack commemoration ceremony
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, Jihadists killed 132 people in shootings and suicide bombings in and around Paris, with the Islamic State group claiming responsibility. Ten years on, a requiem was specifically composed to commemorate the victims.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, Jihadists killed 132 people in shootings and suicide bombings in and around Paris, with the Islamic State group claiming responsibility. Ten years on, a requiem was specifically composed to commemorate the victims.

items.title: Jarvis Cocker's performance at the ceremony commemorating the 2015 terror attacks in Paris
items.standfirst: Ten years ago to the day, coordinated terrorist assaults killed 132 people and wounded at least 350. Many in France and abroad have since described the attacks as the country’s 9/11. Ten years on, the ceremony commemorating the attacks opened with a performance by Jarvis Cocker, leader of the band Pulp.
items.content: Ten years ago to the day, coordinated terrorist assaults killed 132 people and wounded at least 350. Many in France and abroad have since described the attacks as the country’s 9/11. Ten years on, the ceremony commemorating the attacks opened with a performance by Jarvis Cocker, leader of the band Pulp.

items.title: The 'Tree of Justice' lights up at commemoration of the 2015 Paris terror attacks
items.standfirst: France paid an emotional tribute on Thursday to 130 people killed 10 years ago during a rampage by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers targeting cafes, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall. The ceremony opened with a 'Tree of Justice' lighting up, revealing Marianne's face crying.
items.content: France paid an emotional tribute on Thursday to 130 people killed 10 years ago during a rampage by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers targeting cafes, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall. The ceremony opened with a 'Tree of Justice' lighting up, revealing Marianne's face crying.

items.title: Tribute at the Bataclan, 10 years after the Paris attacks
items.standfirst: Emotion filled the streets outside the #Bataclan as #France marked 10 years since the November 13 attacks – remembering the 90 victims of the concert hall tragedy, part of the deadliest terrorist assault in modern French history.
items.content: Emotion filled the streets outside the #Bataclan as #France marked 10 years since the November 13 attacks – remembering the 90 victims of the concert hall tragedy, part of the deadliest terrorist assault in modern French history.

items.title: The Jihadist threat in France: Police have foiled many attacks, but some make it through
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. This marked Paris's second major terrorist attack in the span of a year. Why did French intelligence services fail to anticipate it? Details by Matthew Dalton, Paris correspondent for the Wall Street Journal and Philip Turle, FRANCE 24 International Affairs Editor.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. This marked Paris's second major terrorist attack in the span of a year. Why did French intelligence services fail to anticipate it? Details by Matthew Dalton, Paris correspondent for the Wall Street Journal and Philip Turle, FRANCE 24 International Affairs Editor.

items.title: France honours the 132 victims of the Paris 2015 terrorist attacks
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. Throughout the day Macron, survivors and relatives of victims will honour those killed and wounded at each of the sites of the attacks.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. Throughout the day Macron, survivors and relatives of victims will honour those killed and wounded at each of the sites of the attacks.

items.title: 2015 Paris terror attacks: The longest trial in French history
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. The trial took place from September 2021 to May 2022… making it the longest trial ever held in France. Lou Kiziéla and Simon Moritz look back on this momentous event in French legal history.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. The trial took place from September 2021 to May 2022… making it the longest trial ever held in France. Lou Kiziéla and Simon Moritz look back on this momentous event in French legal history.

items.title: France commemorates 10th anniversary of deadly Paris attacks
items.standfirst: Officials, families and supporters gather across Paris to remember victims killed in deadly November 2015 assaults.
items.content: Officials, families and supporters gather across Paris to remember victims killed in deadly November 2015 assaults.

items.title: Death row inmate granted clemency right before his scheduled execution
items.standfirst: Tremane Wood was scheduled to be executed in Oklahoma on Thursday. Gov. Kevin Sitt commuted his death sentence to life imprisonment without parole.
items.content: Tremane Wood was scheduled to be executed in Oklahoma on Thursday. Gov. Kevin Sitt commuted his death sentence to life imprisonment without parole.

items.title: Oklahoma inmate’s life spared moments before scheduled lethal injection
items.standfirst: Republican Kevin Stitt commuted Tremane Wood’s death sentence to life in prison for 2002 murder of Ronnie WipfAfter a controversial trial, an Oklahoma man makes a final plea to avoid executionTremane Wood, the 46-year-old death row inmate who faced execution on Thursday in Oklahoma, has had his life spared just minutes before he was set to receive a lethal injection.Kevin Stitt, the state’s Republican governor, accepted the Oklahoma pardon and parole board’s recommendation that Wood’s sentence be commuted to life in prison without parole. It is just the second time during Stitt’s nearly seven years as governor that he has granted clemency. Continue reading...
items.content: Republican Kevin Stitt commuted Tremane Wood’s death sentence to life in prison for 2002 murder of Ronnie WipfAfter a controversial trial, an Oklahoma man makes a final plea to avoid executionTremane Wood, the 46-year-old death row inmate who faced execution on Thursday in Oklahoma, has had his life spared just minutes before he was set to receive a lethal injection.Kevin Stitt, the state’s Republican governor, accepted the Oklahoma pardon and parole board’s recommendation that Wood’s sentence be commuted to life in prison without parole. It is just the second time during Stitt’s nearly seven years as governor that he has granted clemency. Continue reading...

clusters.neutral_headline: Verizon To Slash 15,000 Jobs And Shift Hundreds Of Stores To Franchises

items.title: Verizon To Slash 15,000 Jobs And Shift Hundreds Of Stores To Franchises
items.standfirst: Telecom provider Verizon Communications Inc (NYSE:VZ) plans to cut about 15,000 jobs next week. It marks the company’s biggest workforce reduction to date, to slash costs as competition in wireless and home internet intensifies, according to people familiar with the matter. The company will also…
items.content: Telecom provider Verizon Communications Inc (NYSE:VZ) plans to cut about 15,000 jobs next week. It marks the company’s biggest workforce reduction to date, to slash costs as competition in wireless and home internet intensifies, according to people familiar with the matter. The company will also…

items.title: Verizon Eyes Up to 15,000 Layoffs as New CEO Takes Charge
items.standfirst: Verizon Communications Inc. is discussing plans to announce job cuts across the company next week, according to people familiar with the wireless carrier’s plans, a major step in a transformation led by new Chief Executive Officer Dan Schulman.
items.content: Verizon Communications Inc. is discussing plans to announce job cuts across the company next week, according to people familiar with the wireless carrier’s plans, a major step in a transformation led by new Chief Executive Officer Dan Schulman.

items.title: Trump Weighing Military Options to Attack Venezuela Within Days—Report
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Wednesday received updated military options for potential operations in Venezuela, including possible land strikes, according to CBS News. Senior defense leaders, including Secretary of War Pete Hegseth and Joint Chiefs Chairman Dan Caine, briefed the president on…

items.title: Trump said to have received Venezuela military options

items.title: Top officials present Trump with military options for Venezuela in coming days
items.standfirst: The potential operations for Venezuela presented to Trump included options for strikes on land, multiple sources said.
items.content: The potential operations for Venezuela presented to Trump included options for strikes on land, multiple sources said.

clusters.title: Guests ejected mid-stay from bankrupt hotel chain Sonder
clusters.neutral_headline: Guests ejected mid-stay from bankrupt hotel chain Sonder

items.title: Guests ejected mid-stay from bankrupt hotel chain Sonder
items.standfirst: Sonder guests have complained that they had to leave their accommodation as the firm files for a sudden bankruptcy.

clusters.title: The diplomatic gamble that freed French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal
clusters.neutral_headline: French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal pardoned and to be released from prison

items.title: The diplomatic gamble that freed French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Wednesday praised the release of Franco-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal, calling it "the result of respect and calm." The move marks a turning point in the relations between France and Algeria, after months of tension eased through quiet diplomacy and German mediation.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron on Wednesday praised the release of Franco-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal, calling it "the result of respect and calm." The move marks a turning point in the relations between France and Algeria, after months of tension eased through quiet diplomacy and German mediation.

items.title: French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal pardoned and to be released from prison
items.standfirst: Eighty-one year-old, who has prostate cancer, can now be transferred from Algeria to Germany for medical treatmentThe French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal has been pardoned and is to be released from prison, the Algerian presidential office said in a statement on Wednesday.The move, which will mean Sansal can be transferred to Germany for medical treatment, comes after the German president, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, urged Algeria to free Sansal. Continue reading...
items.content: Eighty-one year-old, who has prostate cancer, can now be transferred from Algeria to Germany for medical treatmentThe French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal has been pardoned and is to be released from prison, the Algerian presidential office said in a statement on Wednesday.The move, which will mean Sansal can be transferred to Germany for medical treatment, comes after the German president, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, urged Algeria to free Sansal. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Israeli president condemns ‘serious’ attack by settlers on West Bank villages
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli president condemns ‘serious’ attack by settlers on West Bank villages

items.title: Israeli president condemns ‘serious’ attack by settlers on West Bank villages
items.standfirst: Isaac Herzog makes rare statement on often-ignored violence as settlers injure Palestinians and attack soldiersDozens of masked Israeli settlers attacked Palestinian villages in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday, injuring four Palestinians and attacking Israeli soldiers in the latest incident of rising settler violence.The settlers attacked the Palestinian villages of Beit Lid and Deir Sharaf, setting vehicles on fire and damaging property belonging to a Bedouin community, with charred remains of cars left behind the next day. Continue reading...
items.content: Isaac Herzog makes rare statement on often-ignored violence as settlers injure Palestinians and attack soldiersDozens of masked Israeli settlers attacked Palestinian villages in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday, injuring four Palestinians and attacking Israeli soldiers in the latest incident of rising settler violence.The settlers attacked the Palestinian villages of Beit Lid and Deir Sharaf, setting vehicles on fire and damaging property belonging to a Bedouin community, with charred remains of cars left behind the next day. Continue reading...

items.title: Masked Israeli settlers attack Palestinian villages and IDF soldiers in the West Bank
items.standfirst: Settlers attacked Palestinians and set fire to property in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday before clashing with soldiers sent to break up their rampage.
items.content: Settlers attacked Palestinians and set fire to property in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday before clashing with soldiers sent to break up their rampage.

clusters.title: Trump writes to Israeli president calling for Netanyahu pardon
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump writes to Israeli president calling for Netanyahu pardon

items.title: Trump writes to Israeli president calling for Netanyahu pardon
items.standfirst: Isaac Herzog can pardon convicted criminals in some circumstances, but cases against Israeli PM are ongoingDonald Trump has repeated a request to Israel’s president, Isaac Herzog, for a pardon for Benjamin Netanyahu, who is on trial in three separate corruption cases.The Israeli prime minister has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing in the ongoing court cases. No rulings have been delivered, and his supporters have dismissed the trials as politically motivated. Continue reading...
items.content: Isaac Herzog can pardon convicted criminals in some circumstances, but cases against Israeli PM are ongoingDonald Trump has repeated a request to Israel’s president, Isaac Herzog, for a pardon for Benjamin Netanyahu, who is on trial in three separate corruption cases.The Israeli prime minister has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing in the ongoing court cases. No rulings have been delivered, and his supporters have dismissed the trials as politically motivated. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump asks Israeli president to 'fully pardon' Netanyahu in corruption trial
items.standfirst: Donald Trump has sent a letter to the Israeli president urging him to "fully pardon" Benjamin Netanyahu in his long-running corruption trial.
items.content: Donald Trump has sent a letter to the Israeli president urging him to "fully pardon" Benjamin Netanyahu in his long-running corruption trial.
